questions.question: There was …………………………. hope.
questions.description: Use little with uncountable nouns.

questions.question: Do you know …………………………. guy who works in Australia?
I met ………………………. pretty girls in the store.
questions.description: Much is used with uncountable nouns. Use some in affirmative sentences.

questions.question: I have invited …………………………… my friends.
questions.description: Either all or all of can be used before a noun with a determiner.

questions.question: I have invited …………………………… friend I have.
questions.description: Use all and some with plural nouns.

questions.question: We can’t waste …………………….. more time on this.
There is too ……………………….. salt in the soup.
questions.description: Use much with uncountable nouns.

questions.question: Should I add ………………………….. more salt to the soup?
questions.description: A little indicates a small number.

questions.question: Only ……………………… members voted in favor of the proposal.
questions.description: A few indicates a small number. A little indicates a small quantity.

questions.question: ……………………….. money that I had was spent on drinks.
The ………………………. town was talking about the explosion.
questions.description: All goes before the article whole goes after the article.

questions.question: Can I have ……………………………… fruits?
questions.description: When we expect yes for an answer, some can be used in questions.

questions.question: ………………………….. of us was aware of the happenings.
questions.description: We use plural verbs with all and both. Nobody cannot be used with of us.

questions.question: Who spilled ……………………………. milk on the carpet?
questions.description: Here the emphasis is not on the quantity hence, much is not used. Many and a cannot be used with uncountable nouns like milk.

questions.question: I watched …………………………….. new films last week.
questions.description: Here many or a few is possible. Many indicates a large number a few indicates a small number. Both are grammatically correct here.

questions.question: ……………………………. people were injured in the accident.
questions.description: We can use several or a lot of here.

questions.question: I don’t have …………………………… smartphone.
questions.description: Use a to mean one.

questions.question: She is …………………………….. cleverer than me.
questions.description: We can use a lot to modify comparative adjectives.

questions.question: I did hardly ………………………….. work yesterday.
questions.description: The correct expression is hardly any.

questions.question: There was not …………………………….. room on the bus, so we got off.
………………………………. of the eggs was in the basket.
questions.description: Use a plural verb with all and some.

questions.question: ........................... of these authors is known to me.
questions.description: Neither means not the one nor the other.

questions.question: I don't know ........................... of these authors.
questions.description: Not either means the same as neither. Both is not used in negative sentences.

questions.question: There are very ............................ good restaurants in this town.
questions.description: Very means hardly any.

questions.question: There are .............................. any good restaurants in this town.
questions.description: Hardly any means the same as very few.

questions.question: I have got ............................. cats ........................ dogs.
questions.description: Neither / nor and both/and are possible here with totally opposite meanings.

questions.question: I haven't got ............................. cats ....................... dogs.
questions.description: Both is not used in negative sentences. Not either means the same as neither.

questions.question: ........................... the participants were given a prize.
questions.description: Each and every are followed by singular verbs. All is followed by a plural verb.

questions.question: ............................ the participants was given a prize.
questions.description: We use each of before an article. All of should be followed by a plural verb.

questions.question: You are not better than ....................................
questions.description: Object pronouns are more common after than and as.

questions.question: Even though ......................... my children were born in Mumbai, ......................... of them speaks Marathi.
He has three daughters but .............................. of them lives with him.
questions.description: Either and neither are used to talk about two people or things Use none for more than two.

questions.question: In a football game, ........................... team has 11 players.
questions.description: Each is used to talk about  2 or more. Every is used to talk about 3 or more.

questions.question: .............................. three girls are intelligent and hard working.
.......................... my father and my mother were there at my graduation ceremony.
questions.description: Neither should be followed by a singular verb both should be followed by a plural verb.

questions.question: There was ............................. room on the bus, so we got off.
He hasn't got .......................... a brother or a sister.
questions.description: Neither means the same as not neither. We can also write 'He has got neither a brother nor a sister.'

questions.question: They were .............................. rich nor poor.
questions.description: Neither means not this nor that.

questions.question: ........................... of these answers is correct.
questions.description: Both should be followed by a plural verb.

questions.question: ………………………. them were there.
questions.description: Use both of before a pronoun.

questions.question: There was ………………………….. chance of success.
questions.description: Use little with uncountable nouns.

questions.question: I know ………………………….. man who works in Germany.
questions.description: Use a before nouns with consonant sounds.

questions.question: I have invited …………………………. of my friends to dinner.
questions.description: All of these are possible here with different meanings.

questions.question: I have written to ……………………….. friend I have.
questions.description: Use every before a singular noun.

questions.question: Hurry up! We haven’t got …………………………. time.
questions.description: Use much with uncountable nouns.

questions.question: Add ………………………….. more salt to the soup.
questions.description: A little indicates a small quantity.

questions.question: He has so ………………………… followers on social media.
questions.description: Use many before a plural noun.

questions.question: There aren’t …………………………. flowers on the rose.
questions.description: Use many with plural nouns.

questions.question: The ………………………… town was under water.
questions.description: All goes before the article. Whole goes after the article.

questions.question: I want to ask ............................. questions.
questions.description: A few means a small number few means almost none.

questions.question: .............................. money that I had was not sufficient to buy tickets.
............................... little knowledge of German helped while I was in Switzerland.
She hasn't got .............................. friends.
questions.description: Use many with plural nouns use some in affirmative clauses.

questions.question: ................................. politicians are really honest.
questions.description: Use few with plural nouns.

questions.question: He has ................................ interest in philosophy.
questions.description: Use much with uncountable nouns.

questions.question: Hunger is still rampant in ............................... parts of the world.
Suddenly ................................. lights went out.
questions.description: Use all with plural nouns.

questions.question: I spent the .............................. day in bed.
questions.description: Whole goes after the all goes before the.

questions.question: ………………………… time is needed to complete that project.
questions.description: Use much with uncountable nouns.

questions.question: There weren’t ………………………… students in the class.
questions.description: Use many with plural nouns.

questions.question: I haven’t got ……………………….. interest in politics.
questions.description: Use much with uncountable nouns.

questions.question: My sister has ………………………….. followers on social media.
questions.description: Use many with plural nouns.

questions.question: She is very ……………………….. interested in metaphysics.
She has ……………………………… friends in the film industry.
There aren’t ………………………… fish in the pond.
questions.description: The plural form of fish is fish. Use many with plural nouns.

questions.question: I didn’t do …………………………. work today.
questions.description: Use much with uncountable nouns.

questions.question: I couldn’t answer ………………………….. of the questions.
There isn't .............................. space in this room.
He wasn’t …………………………… concerned about his health.
questions.description: Much can modify adjectives.

questions.question: I could answer only ………………………. questions.
questions.description: Few means almost none a few indicates a small number.

questions.question: She doesn’t have …………………………. friends in the city.
questions.description: Not any means the same as no.

questions.question: I haven’t got ………………………. money.
questions.description: Use much with uncountable nouns and many with plural nouns.

questions.question: I didn’t find ………………………….. there.
questions.description: Not anybody means the same as nobody.

questions.question: There are ……………………………. mangoes on the tree this year.
questions.description: Use fewer with plural nouns and less with uncountable nouns.

questions.question: He earns …………………………. money than I do.
She has …………………………… confidence in her skills.
questions.description: Use little with uncountable nouns and few with plural nouns.

questions.question: You have never given me …………………………… help.
questions.description: Use any with negative expressions like never, hardly etc.

questions.question: …………………………. money has been wasted on that project.
questions.description: Use much with uncountable nouns and many with plural nouns.

questions.question: She has ………………………….. interest in politics.
questions.description: Little is similar to no. It is used with uncountable nouns.

questions.question: We received ……………………………. help from them.
questions.description: Little is used with uncountable nouns.

questions.question: ……………………………. knowledge is a dangerous thing.
questions.description: A little means some or not much. It has a positive meaning.

questions.question: ………………………… students like mathematics.
questions.description: Few means hardly any. It has a negative meaning.

questions.question: I have ……………………………. doubts. Can you clear them?
questions.description: A few means some.

questions.question: …………………………. parks that we have are in poor condition.
questions.description: The few means not many but all that there is.

questions.question: There is ………………………………… water in the bottle.
Can I have ………………………………… to eat?
questions.description: Some is used in interrogative sentences, when we expect an affirmative answer.

questions.question: Is there ……………………………. that we can do?
She doesn’t have ……………………………… patience.
questions.description: Use much with uncountable nouns.

questions.question: I would like to ask ……………………… questions.
questions.description: Use a few to refer to a small number.

questions.question: I didn’t find …………………………… there.
questions.description: Use any, anyone, anybody, anything etc. in questions and negatives.

questions.question: Only ………………………… politicians are really honest.
questions.description: There is not much difference between only a few and very few.

questions.question: ………………………… agreed to come with me.
questions.description: Either someone or no one is possible here. Note that the meanings are different.

questions.question: She doesn’t have ………………………… friends.
questions.description: Use many before a plural noun.

questions.question: I had …………………………… to help me.
questions.description: No one means the same as not anyone.

questions.question: There are …………………………….. birds on the tree.
questions.description: Use some in affirmative sentences.

questions.question: I would like to find …………………………… books on western philosophy.
There are ................................... things I don't like.
questions.description: Some is used in affirmative sentences.

questions.question: Is there ....................................... to help me?
questions.description: Any is used in questions and negatives and also after negative expressions like no one, hardly etc.

questions.question: I have .................................... questions to ask.
questions.description: A few can mean some. It denotes a small number.

questions.question: I would like ...................................... help.
questions.description: Some is used in affirmative sentences.

questions.question: Can ..................................... solve this problem?
questions.description: Any is used in questions and negatives and also after negative expressions like no one, hardly etc.

questions.question: She doesn't have .................................... friends.
questions.description: Any is used in questions and negatives and also after negative expressions like no one, hardly etc.

questions.question: I don't need .................................... help.
questions.description: Any is used in questions and negatives and also after negative expressions like no one, hardly etc.

questions.question: If she is in a bad mood, send her ..................................... flowers.
questions.description: Some is used in affirmative sentences.

questions.question: I couldn't find ................................... books on the subject.
questions.description: Any is used in questions and negatives and also after negative expressions like no one, hardly etc.

questions.question: I haven't got ...................................... cash on me.
questions.description: Any is used in questions and negatives and also after negative expressions like no one, hardly etc.

questions.question: No one has ....................................... idea how they managed to do it.
questions.description: Any is used in questions and negatives and also after negative expressions like no one, hardly etc.

questions.question: They worked hard although there was ……………………….. chance of success.
questions.description: Little is similar to no.

questions.question: ……………………….. money we had helped us immensely.
questions.description: The little means not much but all that there is.

questions.question: There is …………………………. food in the fridge if you are hungry.
questions.description: A little means some or not much. It has a positive meaning.

questions.question: ………………………… foreigners can write perfect English.
questions.description: Few means hardly any. It has a negative meaning.

questions.question: I would like to ask ………………………… questions.
questions.description: A few means some.

questions.question: …………………………. libraries that we have are not properly maintained.
questions.description: The few means not many but all that there is.

questions.question: We did not get …………………………. help.
questions.description: Any is used in negatives and interrogatives.

questions.question: There is …………………………. water in the bottle if you are thirsty.
questions.description: Some is used in affirmative sentences.

questions.question: Will you give me …………………………… to eat?
questions.description: Some is used in interrogative sentences, when we expect an affirmative answer.

questions.question: I haven’t heard ………………………….. from them.
questions.description: Anything is used in negatives.

questions.question: ……………………………… politicians are really honest.
questions.description: We use few with plural nouns.

questions.question: .............................. money was wasted on the project.
……………………….. students attended the class.
questions.description: We use all before a noun without a determiner.

questions.question: The child ate the …………………………. loaf.
questions.description: The determiner (the) goes before whole whereas it goes after all.

questions.question: Does she have …………………………. wealth?
questions.description: We use much before an uncountable noun.

questions.question: …………………………… strength he had proved useless.
questions.description: The little refers to a small amount but it means the whole of that however small it may be.

questions.question: We received …………………………. help from the neighbors.
questions.description: Little means hardly any.

questions.question: She has written …………………………… poems.
questions.description: Many is used with plural nouns.

questions.question: I have read …………………………. word written by her.
questions.description: Every is used with singular nouns all is used with plural nouns.

questions.question: ……………………………… friends he has are all helpful.
He is a man of …………………………… words.
…………………………… words spoken in earnest will convince him.
questions.description: A few means 'a small number'

questions.question: …………………………… man must do his duty.
questions.description: Use every with a singular noun.

questions.question: ……………………….. students attended the class.
questions.description: Use few with plural nouns and little with uncountable nouns.

questions.question: ………………………. my sons can drive.
questions.description: We use neither of before a noun with a determiner.

questions.question: ………………………….. them was there.
questions.description: We use neither of before a pronoun.

questions.question: ………………………… answer is correct.
questions.description: Neither is used without of before a noun without a determiner.

questions.question: ‘She can’t swim.’ ‘I can’t ………………………’
questions.description: Can’t either means the same as neither can.

questions.question: I don’t travel ………………………… these days.
questions.description: Much can be used as an adverb.

questions.question: I haven’t got ……………………….. time.
questions.description: Plenty of is mainly used in affirmative clauses.

questions.question: She has got ……………………………. women friends but she doesn’t know …………………..  men.
questions.description: Many is mainly used in negative and interrogative sentences. In affirmative clauses we prefer plenty of or a lot of.

questions.question: …………………………. cheese is made from cow milk.
questions.description: We use most before a noun without a determiner.

questions.question: …………………………… my friends are non-smokers.
questions.description: We use most of before a noun with a determiner.

questions.question: I won’t pass the exam. I could not answer ………………………….. the questions.
……………………… people believe in ghosts.
questions.description: Before a noun without a determiner, we use most.

questions.question: Has she got ………………………………. friends?
questions.description: In questions we use any some is mainly used in affirmative sentences.

questions.question: …………………………….. key opens the door.
questions.description: Before a noun without a determiner we use neither.

questions.question: …………………………… these answers is correct.
questions.description: We use neither of before a noun with a determiner.

questions.question: ……………………………… my friends wished me on my birthday.
questions.description: None of means not a single one of.

questions.question: I haven’t watched …………………………….. his movies.
questions.description: We use any of before a noun with a determiner.

questions.question: ………………………………. turned up for my party.
questions.description: No one means the same as nobody.

questions.question: I can’t take it ………………………………. longer.
questions.description: No longer is similar to not any longer.

questions.question: ………………………………. his ideas are complicated.
questions.description: We use all of before a noun with a determiner.

questions.question: Can I ask ………………………………. questions?
questions.description: Use 'a few' to mean 'a small number of'.

questions.question: I earn ……………………………. than I used to.
questions.description: Less can be used as an adverb. It is the opposite of more.

questions.question: I found …………………………….. blackberries than you.
questions.description: We use more before the comparative expression than.

questions.question: We haven’t got ………………………………. money.
questions.description: Much is used before an uncountable noun.

questions.question: There aren’t ………………………………. apples on the tree.
questions.description: Many is used before a countable noun.

questions.question: She has got only ………………………………… friends.
questions.description: We use a few before a countable noun.

questions.question: There weren’t …………………………… children in the class.
questions.description: We use many before a plural noun.

questions.question: I have planted …………………………………. roses in the garden.
questions.description: Some is used to indicate an indefinite number or quantity. It is used in affirmative sentences.

questions.question: Is there ………………………………. water in the pond?
questions.description: Any is used in questions and negative sentences.

questions.question: Susie is the ……………………………… popular girl in the class.
………………………………… students hate mathematics.
questions.description: When most means the majority of, it is not used with the.

questions.question: ……………………………… people understand philosophy.
questions.description: Few means hardly any.

questions.question: She didn’t stay for as ……………………………. days as she intended.
questions.description: We use many before a noun without a determiner.

questions.question: You can have as ……………………………….. the juice as you like.
questions.description: Before an article with a determiner, we use much of.

questions.question: They had ……………………….. hope of success yet they persevered.
questions.description: Little means hardly any.

questions.question: The movie was …………………………. interesting.
questions.description: We do not normally use little to modify adjectives or adverbs with a negative meaning.

questions.question: They arrived ………………………….. late.
questions.description: We can use a little before adjectives with a negative meaning.

questions.question: We have got ……………………….. meat.
questions.description: We use a little before uncountable nouns.

questions.question: ……………………………….. people understand philosophy.
questions.description: We use few before a plural noun.

questions.question: Only ………………………….. us are really honest.
questions.description: We use few of before a pronoun.

questions.question: Could I try a …………………………….. your soup?
questions.description: Before a pronoun we use little of.

questions.question: Only …………………………… children in the class passed the test.
questions.description: We use a few before a noun without a determiner.

questions.question: Only …………………………….. the students like math.
questions.description: Before a noun with a determiner we use few of / a few of.

questions.question: An average politician has …………………………… real power.
questions.description: We use little before uncountable nouns.

questions.question: ……………………………….. people can speak a foreign language perfectly.
There weren't ................................ students in the class.
questions.description: We use many before plural nouns and much before uncountable nouns.

questions.question: He doesn't have ................................. patience.
questions.description: We use much before an uncountable noun.

questions.question: We haven't got ............................. time to prepare for the test.
questions.description: We use much before uncountable nouns.

questions.question: I like your parents ............................
questions.description: Much is not normally used with like and dislike in affirmative clauses.

questions.question: I managed to solve the puzzle with .............................. difficulty.
questions.description: We use little before uncountable nouns.

questions.question: I got ............................. apples than her.
questions.description: Fewer is the comparative form of few. We use it before a plural noun.

questions.question: I earn ................................. than my sister.
questions.description: In this context, less is the comparative form of little.

questions.question: We experienced far .................................. problems than we were expecting.
The company does not make ............................... money these days.
............................. want a new system.
questions.description: Many is not normally used alone to mean 'many people'.

questions.question: She is extremely close to ................................. friends she has.
questions.description: The few means not many but all that you have.

questions.question: I .............................. enjoyed my stay with your family.
questions.description: Much can be an adverb.

questions.question: There are only ......................... apples on the tree.
questions.description: Only a few means the same as few.

questions.question: There aren't .............................. apples on the tree.
questions.description: We use many before a plural noun.

questions.question: We don't have ............................ time to finish the work.
questions.description: We use much before an uncountable noun.

questions.question: I collected ................................ money than my brother.
questions.description: We use less before an uncountable noun.

questions.question: Now I have got ............................... problems than I used to have.
questions.description: We use fewer before a plural noun.

questions.question: I solved the problem with ............................. difficulty.
questions.description: We use little before an uncountable noun.

questions.question: There were ............................... people at the party.
questions.description: We use few before a plural noun.

questions.question: There is very ............................ sugar in the jar. We should buy some.
questions.description: We use little before an uncountable noun.

questions.question: There were ................................. students than expected.
questions.description: We use fewer before a plural noun.

questions.question: ........................... politicians are really honest.
questions.description: We use few before a plural noun.

questions.question: She wears ……………………… make-up for my taste.
questions.description: Too much shows undesirable extremes. It is used before an uncountable noun.

questions.question: We got ……………………….. answers to our advertisement.
questions.description: We use too many before a plural noun.

questions.question: I arrived ………………………. early.
questions.description: Before adverbs, we use too, not too much.

questions.question: He is ………………………. generous.
questions.description: Before an adjective without a noun, we use too.

questions.question: It is too …………………………. to go out.
questions.description: We can use too before adjective + a/an + noun.

questions.question: The water is …………………………. salty for us to drink.
questions.description: We cannot use too much before an adjective without a noun.

questions.question: ………………………….. children love animals.
questions.description: When most means the majority of, it is used without the.

questions.question: She didn’t eat ………………………….. breakfast.
questions.description: We use much before a noun without a determiner.

questions.question: You can’t see ………………………… a city in a day.
questions.description: We use much of before a determiner.

questions.question: ……………………….. the people here seem to know each other.
questions.description: We use most of before a noun with a determiner.

questions.question: ……………………………… Indians can understand Hindi.
questions.description: We use most before a noun without a determiner.

questions.question: How ………………………….. you are there?
questions.description: We use many of before a pronoun.

questions.question: ……………………….. people agree with me.
questions.description: Most and many are possible here with slightly different meanings.

questions.question: We meet ……………………….. few days.
questions.description: In a few expressions that refer to time intervals we can use every before a plural noun.

questions.question: …………………………….. these keys opens the door.
questions.description: Before a noun with a determiner (my, this, any etc.) we use neither of.

questions.question: ………………………………. people invited to the party didn’t turn up.
questions.description: We use some, not some of, before a noun without a determiner.

questions.question: ………………………….. the shops remain closed on Sundays.
questions.description: We use most of before a noun with a determiner.

questions.question: ………………………….. philosophy is concerned with life after death.
questions.description: Much of is used before uncountable nouns that refer to a subject of study.

questions.question: ……………………………. his ideas are impractical.
questions.description: Of can be left out after all, both and half when they are followed by nouns.

questions.question: ……………………………. my children love pets.
questions.description: Of can be left out after all, both and half when they are followed by nouns.

questions.question: He spends ……………………………. his income on video games.
questions.description: Of can be left out after all, both and half when they are followed by nouns.

questions.question: ………………………………. us love music.
questions.description: We cannot leave out of after all when it is followed by a pronoun.

questions.question: ………………………….. them was there.
questions.description: We use neither of before a pronoun.

questions.question: ……………………………… these blouses is loose for me.
questions.description: We use every one of before a noun with a determiner.

questions.question: …………………….. tact would have saved the situation.
questions.description: Little means hardly any a little means some, but not much.

questions.question: Of the three, opera, movies and music, the ………………………. is his favorite.
questions.description: Use latter when there are only two things.

questions.question: ……………………… book you mention is out of print.
questions.description: We use ‘the’ to speak of a particular person or thing.

questions.question: I dislike ………………………. fellow.
questions.description: We use ‘the’ to speak of a particular person or thing.

questions.question: …………………….. darkest cloud has a silver lining.
questions.description: We use the with superlatives.

questions.question: Banaras is …………………… holy city.
questions.description: We use ‘a’ in the numerical sense of one.

questions.question: Alladin had ……………………. magic lamp.
questions.description: We use ‘a’ in the numerical sense of one.

questions.question: ……………………. scheme failed for want of support.
questions.description: We use ‘the’ to speak of a particular person or thing.

questions.question: ………………………. people want a new system.
questions.description: We use most before a noun without a determiner.

questions.question: ………………………. these doors leads to the hall.
questions.description: We use neither of before a noun with a determiner.

questions.question: ………………………… the green apples were given to Sarah.
questions.description: We use six of before a noun with an article, possessive or demonstrative.

questions.question: ……………………. of my friends smoke.
questions.description: No is not used before of. Instead we use none.

questions.question: Has she got …………… friends?
questions.description: Any is a Group B determiner. Group B determiners can be used directly before nouns without of.

questions.question: ……………….. children love stories.
questions.description: Most is a Group B determiner. Group B determiners can be used directly before nouns without of.

questions.question: …………….. the shops are closed on Sundays.
questions.description: We use ‘most of’ before a noun with an article, possessive or demonstrative.

questions.question: ……………. philosophy is concerned with life after death.
questions.description: We use much of before place names and nouns that refer to a subject or activity.

questions.question: …………………. these blouses is loose for me.
questions.description: We need ‘of’ before a noun with a determiner. However, we cannot use every before of. We use every one.

questions.question: …………. my friends smoke or drink.
questions.description: We cannot use ‘no’ before ‘of’. Instead we use none.

questions.question: …………….. his ideas are too complicated for me to understand.
questions.description: Before a noun with a determiner, all and all of can both be used.

questions.question: I have invited …………… them to my party.
questions.description: Before a pronoun we use all of.

questions.question: ……………. these keys opens the door.
questions.description: We need ‘of’ before a noun with a determiner.

questions.question: …………… my parents like traveling.
questions.description: Before a noun with a determiner both and both of can both be used.

questions.question: Janet earns …………… money in my family.
questions.description: The most is the superlative of much. Most is used without of before a noun with no determiner.

questions.question: I don't like ....................... of my physics teachers.
questions.description: Not either means the same as neither. The sentence given above can also be written as: I like neither of my physics teachers.

questions.question: ........................... people don't trust politicians.
questions.description: We use most of before a pronoun or a noun with a determiner.

questions.question: Neither .......................................... the door.
questions.description: After either and neither we use a singular noun and a singular verb.

questions.question: Neither of .......................................... valid.
questions.description: After neither of, we use a plural noun and a singular verb.

questions.question: ....................... the shops are closed on Sundays.
questions.description: We use most before a noun without a determiner.

questions.question: They spend ........................... their income on movies.
questions.description: We can leave out of after all, both and half.

questions.question: ................................. my friends wished me on my birthday.
.................................. his ideas are quite interesting.
questions.description: We can leave out 'of' after all when they are followed by nouns.

questions.question: ................................ my children are engineers.
questions.description: We can leave out 'of' after both when they are followed by nouns.

questions.question: His ideas are ............................ different from those of his peers.
The new job isn't ............................... different from the old one.
